I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster will support developing 
member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in effectively identifying high-
level  technology  (HLT)  solutions  for  development  projects.  The  TA  cluster  will  enable 
collaborations with technology providers from the public and private sectors, academia, and 
research institutes, while building capacity in DMCs to develop sustainable projects and programs 
with HLT applications.1 
 
2.  In line with the objective, eligibility criteria, and scope of the High-Level Technology Fund, 
the TA cluster will support DMCs’ decisions to introduce HLT into projects and provide guidance 
on how to proceed to project preparation and due diligence.2 Under the TA cluster, technology 
providers will be invited to offer proposals on HLT prefeasibility studies and innovative solutions 
to address specific development challenges.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Asia and the Pacific has made great progress in economic development and poverty 
reduction. As a result, the region’s development needs have become more diverse, and new 
development challenges have emerged as several DMCs have graduated to middle-income 
status. Many DMCs expect infrastructure with high efficiency, functionality, and faster service 
delivery. Less-developed countries are expanding infrastructure with conventional technology, 
while they aim to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in line with climate change goals. Advanced 
technologies and innovative solutions could provide these DMCs with a range of social, economic, 
and environmental benefits while expanding infrastructure. 
 
4.  HLT includes new and advanced technologies or innovative solutions that can reduce the 
life cycle cost of infrastructure, lower operation and maintenance cost, and increase durability.4 
Modern  and  advanced  equipment  can  improve  efficiency  and  productivity,  thereby  saving 
resources. The adoption of innovative construction methods and technologies can minimize 
negative environmental and social impacts. Innovative approaches and a combination of different 
technologies can also improve the delivery of social services. 
 
5.  However, many DMCs find it challenging to employ HLT in meeting their infrastructure 
development needs. HLT often originates in developed countries, and HLT companies are often 
not familiar with the policies and decision makers of emerging market DMCs. Although these 
companies have better solutions for these DMCs’ development needs, they may not enter these 
markets.  In  addition,  the  skills  and  experience  required  to  develop  detailed  technology 
specifications, evaluate HLT solutions, and identify relevant technology providers are often limited 
in DMCs. But there are several middle-income countries that are becoming technology innovators 
and can share important lessons learnt with other DMCs from developing and implementing 
solutions. They can provide insights on needs and requirements for HLT companies to enter DMC 
markets. 
 
6.  The TA cluster will create a platform for novel engagement with technology providers to 
enable HLT adoptions in collaboration with DMC agencies. The TA cluster will build the capacity

7.  Technology  providers  know  their  technologies  and  their  research  and  development 
pipeline best. By engaging with them through this TA, ADB can leverage their expertise to identify 
HLT solutions to help solve specific challenges in DMCs. By using the HLT Fund implementation 
arrangements under this TA, the early engagement with technology providers will enable them to 
participate in ADB’s competitive procurement processes during project development. 
 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
8.  The HLT Fund was designed such that each sector group may use a TA cluster and seek 
proposals from firms applying HLT in DMCs.5 This modality allows for building a platform for HLT 
applications across sectors, as well as to roll out new approaches to engage with technology 
providers through proposals, before an ADB project is being prepared, while also building capacity 
in DMCs. The TA cluster will create structures and systems to better link ADB knowledge and 
operations with practitioners in DMCs and with HLT providers. In doing so, the cluster approach 
will  enable  systematically  advancing  knowledge  and  technology  solutions  to  address 
development problems. Through a cluster modality, the TA creates a platform for (i) learning from 
each subproject, (ii) expanding the financing of the TA later depending on its success, and (iii) 
developing comprehensive and holistic solutions by engaging with multiple partners. These can 
 
be applied beyond this TA after completion.
 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
9.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impact: use of advanced and innovative 
technologies across ADB operations promoted and capacity building support to DMCs provided.6 
The TA cluster will have the following outcome: DMCs’ ability to evaluate HLT solutions for 
country-specific development challenges enabled.7 
 
10.  Output 1 (subproject 1): ADB innovation knowledge sharing enabled. Under this 
output, innovation assessments building on the Innovative Asia: Advancing the Knowledge-Based 
Economy report series8 will be conducted in selected DMCs. These assessments will focus on 
selected Strategy 2030 operational priority areas, determined based on their relevance to the 
subprojects under outputs 2 and 3. The assessments will aim to (i) understand and define 
development challenges that can be addressed with HLT solutions and (ii) explore and scan what 
kind of HLT innovations are available to address those challenges. The assessments will also 
analyze the enabling environment for HLT applications to understand how to overcome potential 
innovation  barriers  through  policy  dialogue,  capacity  development,  and  investment.  The 
assessments will be conducted through consultation workshops, desktop research, and key 
informant  interviews.  Relevant  sector  and  thematic  groups  will  be  fully  onboard.  Close 
collaboration with the activities under the ADB Ventures Facility, which is being implemented by

dissemination platform, which aims to link the websites of the ADB Ventures Facility, the HLT 
Fund, Development Asia, and the Innovations Speakers’ series. This output will also provide 
technical and facilitation support for outputs 2 and 3. 
 
11.  Output 2 (proposal-based subprojects 2–4): Application of high-level technology 
solutions in the energy sector assessed. This output will test a new engagement modality with 
technology providers to advance HLT innovations in DMCs, beginning with the energy sector.10 
The energy sector group, in close collaboration with DMC experts, will define energy-specific 
development challenges. Such challenges could be related to improving energy efficiency of 
cooling or heating systems, providing clean water in an off-grid environment, or any other energy 
related challenges that have been identified as relevant. Proposals will be sought from technology 
providers to respond to the development challenge with an HLT solution. Based on the selection 
criteria, which will be defined through the TA implementation arrangements, three proposal-based 
subprojects will be selected and implemented. Each technology provider will receive up to 
$500,000 to engage with selected DMCs in order to assess if and how their proposed HLT solution 
could be applied in DMCs. The assessment may include a proof of concept for the HLT application, 
or a rapid prefeasibility study. The results will be shared with DMC counterparts in workshops and 
as case studies through ADB communication channels. The workshops will also be used to build 
DMCs’ capacity to develop specifications for energy-specific development challenges, evaluate 
HLT proposals, and understand how to scale up HLT innovations. 
 
12.  Output 3 (proposal-based subprojects 5–10): Application of high-level technology 
solutions in other sectors assessed. The sector and thematic groups, in close collaboration 
with DMC experts, will identify development challenges related to ADB’s sectors and themes or 
to Strategy 2030 operational priorities that could benefit from HLT solutions. Proposals will be 
sought from technology providers to respond to the development challenge with an HLT solution. 
Based  on  specific  selection  criteria,  which  will  be  defined  through  the  TA  implementation 
arrangements, six proposal-based subprojects will be selected and implemented. The same 
procedures as under output 2 will be followed. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $4,900,000, of which (i) $400,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources)  and  (ii) 
$4,500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the HLT Fund and administered by ADB.11 The 
Technical Assistance Special Fund resources will be used for output 1. The HLT Fund will finance 
outputs 2 and 3 with a maximum of $500,000 for each proposed subproject. Detailed cost 
estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in each TA subproject proposal. The 
selected  technology  providers  may  use  their  own  sources  of funding to  supplement  costs 
exceeding their approved subproject budgets.

C.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will administer the TA cluster. The Knowledge Sharing and Services Center (SDCC-
KS) under the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC) will lead the 
overall implementation, including the subproject under output 1. Subprojects under outputs 2 and 
3 will be administered by SDCC-KS and implemented by the respective sector and thematic 
groups  and  ADB’s  regional  departments.  Ownership  of  the  subprojects  by  the  regional 
departments,  resident missions,  and  DMCs  is  essential.  Experts from respective  sector  or 
thematic groups will form a core group including from SDCC-KS, regional departments, the 
Private  Sector  Operations  Department,  and  resident  missions  to  define  the  development 
challenge—together with the respective DMCs—that will be addressed with HLT solutions.12 This 
challenge will then be developed into a call for proposals that seeks HLT solutions that can meet 
this challenge. The call for proposals will be advertised on www.adb.org and social media such 
as LinkedIn. ADB’s procurement principles of economy, efficiency, fairness, transparency, quality, 
and value for money will be applied. SDCC-KS experts and consultants recruited under subproject 
1 will support this process. The selected proposals will form the subprojects for the TA. 
 
15.  Participating DMCs will be asked to provide their no-objection to this TA. In addition, before 
subproject approval, confirmation will be received from the DMC concerned that the HLT solution 
may be employed within the market and, if not so established, may be tested for suitability for 
market entry or service provision. The participating DMCs will be confirmed for each subproject, 
depending on the call for proposals and the extended expressions of interest (EOIs) received. 
 
16.  Mitigating measures will be undertaken to allow technology providers contracted through 
this TA to remain eligible for downstream business opportunities. Pursuant to the provisions of 
the implementation guidelines for the HLT Fund, the governments accessing ADB funding for 
downstream projects will be encouraged to pursue competitive selection of HLT providers using 
functional specifications that allow wider market participation. In addition, firms engaged through 
this  TA  will  not  be  directly  involved  in  preparing  bid  documents  and  evaluating  bids  for 
downstream contract packages. Moreover, the outputs of the subprojects (e.g., prefeasibility 
studies) will be disclosed to the public, which will ensure that the providers engaged under this 
TA will not have an unfair competitive advantage. With these measures in place, HLT providers 
will be advised that participation in this TA will not preclude them from eligibility to bid for 
subsequent  HLT  contracts  under  ADB-financed  projects.  In  addition,  subproject-specific 
parameters and requirements will be developed regarding intellectual property rights, which may 
result from individual subprojects. Assessments and reports produced under the TA will be made 
publicly available in line with ADB’s Public Communication Policy 2011.

18.  Consulting  services.  Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  support  the 
implementation of subproject 1. International consultant inputs (technical writer and web content 
producer, visual communication expert and graphic designer, and technology innovation expert) 
and national consultant inputs (administrator and finance expert, and auditor) are required to 
support  the  identification  of  the  development  challenges  and  the  assessment  of  ongoing 
innovations in selected DMCs. This will inform the subproject preparation and the engagement

6 
with DMCs, while creating knowledge related to the innovation context in selected DMCs. Output-
based and/or lump-sum contracts will be considered, but time-based contracts will be used as 
appropriate. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are indicative; 
estimates will be finalized before subproject approval in consultation with the sector and thematic 
groups. 
 
19.  Pilot testing of project approach. ADB will assess all proposals under outputs 2 and 3 
to determine if there will be any involuntary resettlement or impact on the environment and 
indigenous peoples. Proposals with minimal or no such impacts will be eligible to receive ADB 
financing. Detailed implementation arrangements for pilot testing will be finalized before the 
approval of each TA subproject in consultation with the government during follow-up missions. 
 
20.  ADB’s procurement. The TA cluster will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time). Lessons learned and best practices in the procurement of HLT will 
be reviewed and adapted as appropriate, for example, from the Organisation for Economic Co-
operation  and  Development’s  framework  of  public  procurement  for  innovation.13 ADB  will 
customize procurement documentation to fit the purpose. This would include specific procurement 
arrangements, with corresponding risk-mitigation measures, to (i) not exclude the participating 
HLT providers from supplying the solutions in response to downstream tenders in ADB-financed 
projects and (ii) provide the ability to award pre-commercialization gap-mitigation contracts to 
more than one qualified proponent. The submitted extended EOIs will be evaluated by a team of 
experts  from  SDCC;  the  regional  department  sector  or  thematic  experts;  SDCC-KS;  the 
Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management Department; and the HLT Fund manager. 
Each subproject will require the endorsement of the head of the respective regional department 
and  the  respective  country  director.  Detailed  procurement  arrangements,  emphasizing  fair 
competition and transparency and addressing any intellectual property rights issues, will be 
finalized before approval of each TA subproject. 
 
21.  Social media and websites. The TA cluster will use ADB-supported website and social 
media channels that are maintained by SDCC-KS and follow the ADB Guidelines on Social Media 
and the Branding Tool Kit.14 
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $4,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund; 
and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
Support for Innovation and Technology Partnerships in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
1.  For subproject 1, individual consultants will be recruited to support Asian Development 
Bank staff and developing member country experts in line ministries and in the ministry of science 
and technology or equivalents to (i) identify key development challenges, (ii) understand what 
kind of high-level technology (HLT) solutions are in use in a country, (iii) identify what the 
bottlenecks are for scaling up or introducing new HLT applications, and (iv) develop case studies 
and lessons learned. The consultants will also support consultation workshops as needed. To 
support this process, individual consultants will be recruited to develop digital content and visual 
communication material for the Asian Development Bank’s digital innovation platform. Short 
reports, visual summaries, infographics, and multimedia content will also be produced. 
 
2.  For  subprojects  2–10,  three  energy-related  subprojects  and  six  other  sector-related 
subprojects will be developed under output 2. The sector and thematic groups will develop the 
call for proposals together with government agencies of the respective developing member 
country based on identified development challenges. Based on the selected technology providers’ 
proposals, the detailed subproject budget and summary subproject work plans will be developed 
by the sector group, led by the regional department sector or thematic expert and submitted to 
heads of departments for approval. The subproject proposals will be disclosed on the HLT website.
